content:
At the Enter password prompt, you enter the special app password, but do you select the checkbox 'Remember Password' so that password manager saves it ?

If no then this explains why it is not saved. At the next password prompt enter password and select the checkbox to remember password.

If yes, you do select checkbox to remember password please then check to see if it really is saved in Thunderbird?

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • click on 'Show Passwords'

Do you see the account - there should be at least two lines one for incoming and one for outgoing and is the Password the correct special app password.

If yes, it is being saved, so why has this gone when you next start Thunderbird ? Check for programs on your computer which clean up files such as session, temp or password. eg: CCleaner or WiseCleaner or some Anti-virus products If you use these products then I would advise that you make your Thunderbird profile exempt from scanning. They are known to be a nuisance when it comes to deleting files that are required in Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: At the Enter password prompt, I enter the special app password and select the checkbox 'Remember Password' so that password manager saves it. In the password there is only one lines for incoming, none for outgoing, why?

content: Enter password and select the checkbox to remember the password before you click on OK Then password is remembered in Thunderbird and gets auto used so you do not have to keep entering it everytime there's a new connection to the server.

content:
Please do a bit of checking.

Open the stored passwords and check that the correct password is stored is the first thing.

If the password is correct then the issue is one of the connection failing or being refused, not really a password one. Thunderbird asks for a password when the connection fails and failure is not always caused by the password.

Next log the pop connection

  1. open the config editor and change the setting mailnews.pop3.loglevel, to All
  2. open the error console (ctrl+Shift+J) and clear it using the little trash icon.
  3. Ask Thunderbird to get message for the account.
  4. Refer to the error console and see what messages have appeared.
  5. Right click the messages in the list and select copy all messages.
  6. in a reply on the forum paste the copied messages into a reply so we can see what is going on.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
You and other employees are using same mail account - same main work e-mail account. I would expect that all employees and you are using IMAP mail accounts. Are you using IMAP mail account?

The set of Tags would need to be exactly the same on all computers for all computers to see the same. Each person with access to the account must manually create/duplicate the named tag(s) in question. Find out what set of tags all the other computers are using.

If you tag email with AP which is $label3.tag, but that tag reference is different on other computers then it may be causing a conflict.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re :the string relates to a tag that doesn't have a number assigned (?)

The number assigned can only go up to 9 as there is no such thing as 10 :) But number eg: 9 can mean different things on different computers, so applying a number may not be the best method in all cases. I've got one without a number as I've set up 10 tags.

The assigned number is the shortcut key assigned to them in the menu. eg: 'Important' tag is set up and assigned number 1 in Tags list. select email in list and press number 1 on keyboard will auto set 'Important ' tag.
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: mary100661

content: I'm not sure what's happening, but here's a suggestion: Before you do the group mailing, mail the document to the first person on your list (only). That should be copied to your Sent folder on the server, so that if you need to send it again to someone else, it will be easy. Then send the bulk mailing out to all of the other addresses. If the server won't make large-group copies of a single document in the Sent folder, your initial copy is good, and provides a record of the mailing transaction. If that doesn't work for you, I think you'll have to check with your email handler online, to see what's going on with bulk mailings not being copied to Sent. It might be important to set your Sent Mail instruction with the Other option, and use the drop-arrow to see the choices. Choose the server's Sent folder, not the local IMAP one. I get better results from that method.
creator: danawilson001

content:
To apply an OpenPGP alias to the account level in Thunderbird, you can follow these steps:

Open Thunderbird and go to "Tools" > "Account Settings."

In the Account Settings window, select the email account for which you want to apply the OpenPGP alias.

Under the "OpenPGP Security" tab, check the box that says "Enable OpenPGP support for this account."

Click on the "Manage OpenPGP keys" button. This will open the OpenPGP Key Manager.

In the OpenPGP Key Manager, select the key associated with your email account and click on the "Properties" button.

In the Key Properties window, go to the "Aliases" tab.

Click on the "Add" button and enter the desired alias for your account.

You can also select the checkbox that says "Use as default for this account" if you want to set the alias as the default for this account.

Click "OK" to save the changes.
creator: techguy150

content:
Thank you David. I have just gone to install the OWL addon but it wants full unrestricted access to my computer.. Not sure I feel comfortable with that. I found this about it.

"Have full, unrestricted access to Thunderbird, and your computer:

The extension is using an older technology and has full access to Thunderbird’s internal APIs and does not need to request individual permissions. Up to Thunderbird 68 almost every add-on had this unrestricted access without specifically asking for it. Add-ons request this permission, as long as the new permission based API system does not yet offer the functionality they need.

Extensions requesting this permission might: 

   Change every aspect of Thunderbird’s user interface    Read and modify all your data (messages, contacts, calendars, web content and passwords)    Read, modify and execute any file on your computer"


Read, modify and excute any file on my computer? Is this addon trust worthy enough to give it that kind of permission?

Thanks, James

The text/warning you are seeing is boiler plate legalese. It doesn't actually mean that every add-on will do those things in an inappropriate way.

content: I'll answer number2: Thunderbird offers 'unified folders', a simple click that creates a virtual inbox. As far as Pocomail, I've seen some propriety conversion tools. However - and this is a long shot - I think Eudora uses MBX format. if true, you could export to MBX, install Eudora 8 (a precursor of a eudora/thunderbird marriage) and that would create TB-compatible messages (which I have confirmed by converting a Eudora account to TB0, and then importing that to thunderbird. That approach may require a few tweaks, but it may do just what you want.
creator: davidsk

content: What you're describing is a a POP account, but I surmise that you have an IMAP account, which doesn't work that way. If that is your desire, I suggest you create a POP account and then remove the IMAP account (they can coexist during the transition.) If you prefer to keep the IMAP account, then you would need to create a folder in Local Folders, copy desired messages there, and then manually delete the messages from online.

content:
To transfer old emails from a Thunderbird POP account to a new Thunderbird Owl-EWS (Exchange Web Services) account, you can follow these steps:

Set up the Owl-EWS account in Thunderbird:

Open Thunderbird and go to "Tools" > "Account Settings." Click on "Account Actions" and select "Add Mail Account." Enter your name, email address, and password for the Owl-EWS account. Thunderbird will automatically configure the account using Owl-EWS settings. Enable the Owl-EWS account to access old POP emails:

In Thunderbird, go to "Tools" > "Account Settings." Select the Owl-EWS account from the left sidebar. Under the "Server Settings" tab, check the box that says "Allow immediate server notifications when new messages arrive." Click on "Advanced" and check the box that says "Include this server when getting new mail." Transfer emails from the POP account to the Owl-EWS account:

In Thunderbird, go to the POP account folder that contains the old emails you want to transfer. Select the emails you want to move by holding down the "Ctrl" key (or "Cmd" key on Mac) and clicking on each email. Right-click on the selected emails and choose "Move To" > "Owl-EWS account" > "Inbox" (or the desired folder in the Owl-EWS account). Thunderbird will start moving the selected emails to the Owl-EWS account.
creator: techguy150

content: Since you have the old folders on your PC, a simple approach may be to exit thunderbird and in Windows FIle Explorer, locate the folders within the profile and copy to the Mail\Local Folders folder in the profile. Then restart thunderbird and verify that all the folders are working properly and then remove the old POP account.
